An Indonesia official was shown a red card amid the chaotic scenes after the match.
The Indonesian Football Association (PSSI) has formally submitted a protest letter to both FIFA and the Asian Football Confederation (AFC) regarding the controversial refereeing.
The unfair result for Indonesia's national team could potentially lead to a legal challenge, and a rematch could be arranged.
PSSI's complaint focuses on the referee Ahmed Al-Kaf’s decision to extend stoppage time beyond the indicated six minutes, allowing Bahrain to equalize.
The protest specifically highlights the referee’s failure to consult the Video Assistant Referee (VAR) system for a possible offside on Bahrain’s equalizing goal.
The public, especially Indonesian netizens, reacted strongly to the incident, with the hashtag #Wasit becoming a trending topic in Indonesia on the X platform with over 212,000 tweets.
PSSI argued that the additional time was unjustified and raised concerns that the referee appeared to be waiting for Bahrain to score.
Indonesia were disappointed and furious about the extended added time which led to Bahrain's equalizer.
Shin Tae-yong called the referee’s decision in this match biased, which caused the Indonesian national team players to express anger at the end of the match.
Indonesian national team coach Shin Tae-yong expressed disappointment about referee Ahmed Al Kaf’s leadership during the match.
The Indonesian national team lodged a strong protest, arguing that the referee's decision had put them at an unfair disadvantage.
FIFA has not yet released an official response to the protest.
